package_identity.package_description: Statutory services for children and young people aged 0-25 with special educational needs and/or disabilities, including Education, Health and Care needs assessments, EHC plan coordination, the Local Offer, and support for families throughout the SEND process

service_overview.what_is_send: Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) services support children and young people aged 0-25 who have additional needs that require support beyond what is ordinarily available in mainstream settings. Gloucestershire County Council has a statutory duty to identify, assess, and make provision for children and young people with SEND, working in partnership with health and social care.
what_it_provides: Education, Health and Care (EHC) needs assessments
EHC plan coordination, issue, and annual review
The Local Offer - information about available SEND provision
SEND Information, Advice and Support Service (SENDIASS)
Specialist educational provision including special schools and resourced units
Post-16 and post-19 SEND support up to age 25
Short breaks and respite for disabled children and their families
Specialist support services (advisory teachers, inclusion support)

who_it_serves.population: Children and young people with special educational needs and/or disabilities resident in Gloucestershire
who_it_serves.note: EHC plans can continue to age 25 for those in education or training. Young people aged 16+ have rights in their own name under the Children and Families Act 2014.

partner_agencies: NHS Gloucestershire Integrated Care Board (ICB) - health element of EHC plans
Gloucestershire Health and Care NHS Foundation Trust - specialist health services
District and city councils - housing and some social care interfaces
Schools and academies - delivery of SEND support

primary_legislation.what_law_requires: Local authorities must identify, assess and make provision for children and young people with SEND aged 0-25. Where a child or young person has or may have SEND and has or may have needs that cannot be met by support ordinarily available, the authority must conduct an EHC needs assessment.

key_sections.purpose: Principles: local authority must have regard to the views, wishes and feelings of the child/young person and their parents, importance of participation, importance of achieving best possible outcomes
Local authority must keep under review education and training provision and social care provision for children and young people with SEND in its area (Local Offer duty)
EHC needs assessments - duty to assess
Educational placement in EHC plans - mainstream preference and parental choice
Duty to name requested school/institution in EHC plan (s.39) and naming alternative (s.40)
Duty to secure special educational provision specified in EHC plan
Mediation and appeals - right to mediation before tribunal, SEND Tribunal jurisdiction
Local authority's duty to provide information and advice (SENDIASS)

legal_status.statutory_authority: Children and Families Act 2014 places mandatory duties on local authorities. These are not discretionary.
legal_status.right_of_appeal: Parents and young people have a right of appeal to the First-tier Tribunal (SEND) against decisions on EHC needs assessments, the contents of EHC plans, and decisions to cease plans.
challenge_routes: Mediation (mandatory to consider before Tribunal appeal in most cases)
First-tier Tribunal (Special Educational Needs and Disability) - commonly called the SEND Tribunal
Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman - for process failures

ehc_needs_assessment.what_it_is: An Education, Health and Care (EHC) needs assessment is a detailed look at the special educational, health and social care needs of a child or young person. It considers whether an EHC plan is needed to secure the provision required.
who_can_request: Parents or carers of a child or young person aged 0-25
Young people aged 16-25 in their own name
Anyone else who thinks an assessment may be necessary (with parent/young person knowledge)

how_to_request.method: Written request to Gloucestershire County Council SEND team

decision_to_assess.timescale_description: Local authority must decide whether to carry out an EHC needs assessment within 6 weeks of receiving a request
decision_factors: Whether the child or young person has or may have special educational needs
Whether it may be necessary to make special educational provision through an EHC plan
Evidence of needs and what has been tried in the educational setting

if_refused.right: Parent/young person can appeal refusal to assess to the SEND Tribunal
if_refused.timescale_to_appeal: Must mediate or obtain mediation certificate before appealing; 2 months from decision or 1 month from mediation certificate (whichever is later)

the_assessment.overall_timescale_description: From request to EHC plan issue (or notice that plan will not be issued) must be within 20 weeks, except in exceptional circumstances
who_contributes: Health advice (coordinated by NHS Gloucestershire ICB)
Child or young person's views (including through the Education, Health and Care assessment)
Any other specialist advice requested (e.g. speech and language therapy, occupational therapy, specialist advisory teacher)
the_assessment.childs_voice: The views, wishes and feelings of the child or young person must be ascertained and given due weight throughout the assessment process (Children and Families Act 2014, s.19)

options: Decide not to issue an EHC plan (with reasons and right of appeal)
decision_after_assessment.notification_timescale: Within 16 weeks of the request (decision whether to issue plan)
decision_after_assessment.draft_plan_timescale: Draft EHC plan sent to parents/young person within 15 working days of decision to issue

ehc_plans.what_it_is: An Education, Health and Care (EHC) plan is a legal document describing a child or young person's SEND, the outcomes sought, and the educational, health and social care provision to meet those needs and achieve those outcomes.

sections.content: Views, interests and aspirations of the child/young person and parents
Social care needs related to SEND
Outcomes sought for the child/young person
Special educational provision (this section is legally binding)
Health provision (this section is legally binding on the NHS ICB)
Social care provision under Children Act 1989 s.2 Chronically Sick and Disabled Persons Act 1970
Appendices - advice and information gathered during assessment

legally_binding_sections.explanation: Sections B (needs), F (educational provision) and G (health provision) are the legally binding sections. The local authority has a duty to secure all provision specified in Section F. The NHS ICB has a duty to arrange provision specified in Section G.

placement.general_principle: Children and young people with EHC plans must be educated in mainstream provision unless this is incompatible with parental wishes, or incompatible with the efficient education of others and there are no reasonable steps to prevent that incompatibility (Children and Families Act 2014, s.33)
placement.parental_preference: Parents can request a particular school or institution. The local authority must name it unless it is unsuitable for the child's needs, or the attendance would be incompatible with efficient education of others or efficient use of resources.
placement_types: Mainstream school with specialist resourced unit or provision
Independent special school (approved under s.41 Children and Families Act 2014)

annual_review.frequency: At least annually for all EHC plans
annual_review.legal_reference: Children and Families Act 2014, s.44; SEND Regulations 2014, Regulation 18-20

phase_transfer_reviews.timing: By 31 March in year before school entry
By 31 March in Year 5 (year before Year 6, i.e. 2 years before transfer)
By 31 March in Year 9, and every year thereafter until leaving school

review_process: School/setting sends invitations and paperwork at least 2 weeks before review meeting
Recommendations sent to local authority within 2 weeks of meeting
Local authority decides within 4 weeks of meeting to maintain, amend or cease plan

grounds: Young person is no longer in education or training
Local authority determines plan is no longer necessary (e.g. needs met, outcomes achieved)
ceasing_an_ehc_plan.right_of_appeal: Parents and young people have the right to appeal a decision to cease an EHC plan to the SEND Tribunal

personal_budgets.what_it_is: A personal budget gives families or young people more control over how the special educational provision in their EHC plan is delivered
types: Arrangements (provider delivers on behalf of authority)
Direct payments (money paid to family or young person to commission provision themselves)
personal_budgets.right_to_request: Parents and young people have the right to request a personal budget when an EHC plan is being prepared or reviewed
personal_budgets.legal_reference: Children and Families Act 2014, s.49; Special Educational Needs (Personal Budgets) Regulations 2014

graduated_approach.what_it_is: The graduated approach is a model for identifying and meeting SEND needs through cycles of action, starting with support ordinarily available in educational settings, before escalating to additional support and potentially an EHC needs assessment.

the_cycle.assess: Identify and assess the child or young person's needs
the_cycle.plan: Create a plan of support with targets and provision
the_cycle.review: Review the impact and adjust accordingly

waves_of_support.description: Quality-first teaching and ordinarily available provision for all pupils, including those with SEND
Additional targeted support for pupils who need more than ordinarily available provision, typically through SEND Support with a plan
waves_of_support.responsibility: School SENDCo and class teachers, may involve external advisory support

waves_of_support.description: Where targeted support has not met needs, an EHC needs assessment may be appropriate
waves_of_support.responsibility: Local authority EHC process with school involvement

send_support_in_school.legal_basis: Children and Families Act 2014 and SEND Code of Practice
send_support_in_school.requirements: Schools must use best endeavours to make special educational provision for pupils with SEN. Schools must identify, assess and plan support for pupils with SEN through the graduated approach.

sendco.role: Every maintained school and academy must have a qualified teacher designated as SENCO (Special Educational Needs Co-ordinator)
sendco.legal_reference: Children and Families Act 2014, s.67; SEND Regulations 2014, Regulation 49-51
sendco.qualifications: SENDCos who are new to the role must achieve the National Professional Qualification for SENCOs (NPQSENCO) within 3 years of appointment

local_offer.what_it_is: The Local Offer sets out the support available for children and young people with SEND and their families in Gloucestershire, from early years through to adulthood. It must be published and kept up to date.

what_must_be_included: Special educational provision in maintained schools, academies, early years providers and post-16 institutions
Health and social care provision for children and young people with SEND
Other educational provision (independent schools, alternative provision)
Information about support available to assist in preparation for adulthood
Training and support for parents and carers

eyfs_send_support.sendco_equivalent: Every maintained nursery school and other maintained settings must have a SENCO. Other providers should have a named person for SEND coordination.
eyfs_send_support.disability_access_fund: Children aged 3-4 with certain disabilities receiving Disability Living Allowance may attract a Disability Access Fund (DAF) payment to their early years provider to improve access

transition_to_adulthood.legal_framework: Children and Families Act 2014 and Care Act 2014 together govern transition; SEND Code of Practice Chapter 8
transition_to_adulthood.when_planning_starts: Transition planning must begin at the Year 9 annual review (age 13-14) and continue through annual reviews until the young person leaves education or reaches 25
preparation_for_adulthood_domains: Higher education and/or employment (including supported employment)
Participation in society (including leisure and volunteering)
Being as healthy as possible in adult life

adult_social_care.care_act_assessment: Young people with SEND approaching 18 may be eligible for an adult social care needs assessment under the Care Act 2014
adult_social_care.transition_assessment: Local authority must assess where it appears a young person is likely to have needs for care and support after turning 18
adult_social_care.timing: Must be carried out at a time that is of significant benefit to the young person, usually between 16-18

ehc_plan_to_age_25.duration: EHC plan can continue to age 25 if the young person remains in education or training
ehc_plan_to_age_25.ceasing: Plan must be ceased when young person leaves education or training, reaches 25, or when needs can be met without a plan
